data.title: GWT compilation error when using annotations with Class property set to primitive type
NullPointerException thrown when AssetLoader.getDependencies returns null
data.body:
Using latest nightlies, `AssetManager` now crashes with NullPointerException when attempting to load assets with no dependencies, using custom loaders.

The cause is here:
https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/commit/491f2646309e3d71f41ca7dbc8e02b5e09ba98d3#diff-d0ba77a9cde8d11730d759b7be8e8df8R101

As you can see, `dependencies == null`. But then, in `removeDuplicates`, the code is trying to access `array.ordered` which causes the NPE.

The code probably shouldn't even be trying to do anything with `dependencies` since it's `null`.

data.title: Fixed ScrollPane scrolling for very large heights
data.body:

Four extra fields were also included so the mouseScroll amount can be customized as well as the smooth scrolling animation speeds

data.title: Add Mappings for Xbox 360 Controller
data.body:
This adds mappings for the Xbox 360 controller. See #2185 for my previous attempt.

Tested on Windows, OS X and Linux.

The GWT emulation is based on the Ouya emulation and the uses the [Standard Gamepad Layout](https://w3c.github.io/gamepad/#remapping). However, I could not test the GWT emulation, because libgdx does not recognize my controller in the browser (it shows up fine [here](http://www.html5rocks.com/en/tutorials/doodles/gamepad/gamepad-tester/tester.html)).

I also refactored the controller test so that it does not spam you with axis updates, but instead only shows the last value.

data.title: Add Focusable support
data.body:
This PR adds basic support for focusing more than `TextField` instances. Also it modifies the way in which focusable instances are found (it uses the Cocoa way, with a field containing the next or previous instance to focus)

My idea is adding support for `List`s to be able to use the keyboard to navigate them, or be able to mark `CheckBox`es with Space, etc (no implementation of that is done yet, I want to know first what you thikn about this one). Also, being able to deterministically set which field is the next/previous one to be focused is also very useful.

data.title: TextField selection is off when using NinePatch
data.body:
When you create a skin for `TextField` using a `NinePatch`, the selection and caret positions are off by the left size of the `NinePatch`. Example:

``` java
val textFieldStyle = TextField.TextFieldStyle(
        font, Color.WHITE,
        TextureRegionDrawable(TextureRegion(Texture("caret.png"))),
        TextureRegionDrawable(TextureRegion(Texture("caret.png"))),
        NinePatchDrawable(NinePatch(Texture("textField.png"), 30, 30, 2, 2))
)
skin.add("default", textFieldStyle)
val textField = TextField("This is some text...", skin)
table.add(textField).center().row()
```

With that code, your textfield will have a 30px left and right "margin". When you click on the text inside the `TextField`, the caret won't be positioned where you clicked, but 30px to the right. Selections are also obviously affected.

data.title: Add ShaderTester, it wraps Khronos shader compiler
data.body:
This PR adds a thin wrapper around the the [official Khronos reference shader compiler](https://github.com/KhronosGroup/glslang), it can process
whole directories and shaders as Strings.

There are some open questions:
It should be also possible to directly use the compiler through JNI, this would remove the limitation, that e.g. fragment shader MUST have .frag as extension.
But I don't know anything about JNI and jnigen.

Mac support is not available because, there are no binaries available for Mac.

The biggest problem is https://github.com/intrigus/libgdx/blob/9a4e6620b0d96116803b521f994d6d447e084104/extensions/gdx-tools/src/com/badlogic/gdx/tools/shadertester/ShaderTester.java#L41-L105 this is stolen from SharedLibraryLoader.getExtractedFile(). The method I copied is private so I'd have to invoke SharedLibraryLoader.getExtractedFile() through Reflection, which would remove duplicated code, but I don't like relying on Reflection.

data.title: [feature request]Does libgdx need a scripting language? Ideas and possible contributors as well as possible problems.
data.body:
Libgdx has a JSON parser and a XML parser. It is my opinion that it should also feature a wrapper that supports the creation of basic scripts, either using a unique language or a language that already exists. I would be willing to write some of the code for this, but before I commit to thousands of lines of coding I would like to get an idea of how many people would use this.

Many great game engines and frameworks use scripting languages to avoid the need to recompile games when making changes. It is, as a matter of fact, [recommended to use a scripting language](http://gamedev.stackexchange.com/questions/2913/why-do-we-use-scripts-in-development/2914#2914) for large projects. While most libgdx projects are small, some can be pretty big. For example, I was compiling my game to test it and it took fifteen minutes to complete. This is annoying, and I toyed around with the concept of creating my own scripting language, but the idea of debugging 2000+ more lines of code by myself was daunting.  It seems better and more efficient to break the work up between multiple devs than to try and accomplish such a task alone.

I want to keep with the reusable and extendable tradition of libgdx and have drafted the following (rough) graph of how the engine could work;

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10172349/10140923/7483b158-65cf-11e5-9cbd-802deb7aa736.jpg)

The Parser would be an interface to handle the syntax of the script while the Interpreter (an abstract class and the real meat) would handle expressions and logic. The java implementation would, of course, be custom implementations of the interfaces which tie together into a controlling class which can be instantiated in your create method and implemented in your render method.

Would this fit well with the main project? Should I add it to the main project?  Any ideas on how to implement it?

data.title: Hiero does not support GPOS kerning
data.body:
Apparently the font I'm using (Fredoka One, [available for download here](http://www.1001freefonts.com/fredoka_one.font)) doesn't have any kerning data in the `kern` table, but it does in the [more advanced `GPOS` (glyph positioning) table](https://www.microsoft.com/typography/otspec/GPOS.htm), which Hiero doesn't seem to support.

I might have a shot at adding such support, but maybe somebody knows of a workaround? I looked at converting `GPOS` to `kern` using FontForge, but if it's possible I couldn't figure out how.

data.title: Add support for Vibration on GWT
data.body:
This PR adds support for vibration on GWT.
Repeated patterns are emulated, because the api doesn't support that.

There is a problem:
It's not possible to detect whether a device has a vibrator.
We can only check if the browser supports the vibration API, so it's possible that the browser supports vibration, but the device has no vibrator.

That's why Input.isPeripheralAvailable(Peripheral#Vibrator) does return true, if the browser supports vibration. 

I also added a better test.
